docTitle.titlePart:
Muscle stem cells differentiate into haematopoietic
lineages but retain myogenic potential

byline.docAuthor:
Baohong Cao 1 , Bo Zheng 1 , Ron J. Jankowski 1 , Shigemi Kimura 2 , Makoto Ikezawa 2 , Bridget Deasy 1 ,
James Cummins 1 , Mike Epperly 3 , Zhuqing Qu-Petersen 1 and Johnny Huard 1,4

front.div:
Muscle-derived stem cells (MDSCs) can differentiate into
multiple lineages, including haematopoietic lineages 1â€“12 .
However, it is unknown whether MDSCs preserve their
myogenic potential after differentiation into other lineages. To
address this issue, we isolated from dystrophic muscle a
population of MDSCs that express stem-cell markers and can
differentiate into various lineages 1,13 . After systemic delivery
of three MDSC clones into lethally irradiated mice, we found
that differentiation of the donor cells into various lineages of
the haematopoietic system resulted in repopulation of the
recipients' bone marrow. Donor-derived bone-marrow cells,
isolated from these recipients by fluorescence-activated cell
sorting (FACS), also repopulated the bone marrow of
secondary, lethally irradiated, recipients and differentiated into
myogenic cells both in vitro and in vivo in normal mdx mice.
These findings demonstrate that MDSC clones retain their
myogenic potential after haematopoietic differentiation.
